verses.text: Hear the word of the LORD, O people of Israel! For the LORD has a charge against the inhabitants of the land: there is no faithfulness or steadfast love, and no knowledge of God in the land.
verses.comment: The phrase 'no knowledge of God' underlines Israel’s covenant failure and recalls similar indictments in Isaiah and Jeremiah. The lack of faithfulness and love reflects a breach in the relationship God intended. The Hebrew term for 'steadfast love' (chesed) points toward God’s desired covenantal loyalty, later embodied in Christ’s sacrificial love.

verses.text: There is only swearing, lying, killing, stealing, and committing adultery; they break all bounds, and bloodshed follows bloodshed.
verses.comment: These are clear violations of the Ten Commandments. The breakdown of moral order is emphasized here, showing societal collapse when God's law is rejected. This anticipates Christ's call to fulfill, not abolish, the law (see Matt. 5:17).

verses.text: Therefore the land mourns, and all who live in it languish; the beasts of the field, the birds of the heavens, and even the fish of the sea are taken away.
verses.comment: Human sin causes creation itself to suffer. This connection echoes Genesis and Paul’s teaching in Romans 8:22, emphasizing that the created order is affected by human rebellion and awaits redemption.

verses.text: Yet let no one contend, and let none accuse, for your people are like those who contend with the priest.
verses.comment: Contending with the priest refers to rebelliousness against God’s appointed authority. The reverence for priestly ministry in the Old Covenant foreshadows the New Covenant’s enduring priesthood (see Heb. 5:6).

verses.text: You stumble by day and the prophet also stumbles with you by night; I will silence your mother.
verses.comment: 'Your mother' stands for the nation. Both people and prophet fall into error, indicating communal accountability. This sets up the pattern for God working restoration through His chosen messengers.

verses.text: My people are destroyed for lack of knowledge; because you have rejected knowledge, I reject you from being priest to me. Since you have forgotten the law of your God, I also will forget your children.
verses.comment: The emphasis is on knowledge of God and the consequences of neglecting His law. The connection between rejection of knowledge and loss of priesthood points toward God’s desire for a faithful, knowledgeable leadership—a theme picked up in 1 Peter 2:9 (the 'royal priesthood') and connected to Christ as High Priest.

verses.text: The more they multiplied, the more they sinned against me; I will change their glory into shame.
verses.comment: Here, increase in population brings increase in sin, inverting the blessing promised to Abraham (Gen. 22:17). Their 'glory'—possibly the priesthood or God's favor—is turned into shame, prefiguring the reversal of fortunes promised in Christ (Phil. 2:5-11).

verses.text: They feed on the sin of my people; they are greedy for their iniquity.
verses.comment: Priests in Hosea’s day profited from people’s sin offerings, showing corruption. It contrasts with the selfless model of the true Servant, ultimately Christ (see Heb. 7:26-27).

verses.text: And it will be like people, like priest: I will punish both for their ways, and repay them for their deeds.
verses.comment: There is no favoritism; both leaders and the people are judged. This sets a pattern for accountability that is echoed in Paul’s teaching and in Christ’s warnings to hypocritical leaders (Matt. 23:27-28).

verses.text: They will eat, but not have enough; they will play the whore, but not increase, because they have forsaken the LORD to cherish prostitution.
verses.comment: The consequences are spiritual as well as physical—idolatry and sexual immorality lead to emptiness and frustration, foreshadowing Jesus’ teaching on the Bread of Life (John 6:35).

verses.text: Whoredom, wine, and new wine take away understanding.
verses.comment: Unfaithfulness and intoxication cloud judgment, a warning throughout Scripture. The repeated admonition anticipates the call to be sober and spiritually vigilant (1 Pet. 5:8).

verses.text: My people consult their wooden idols, and a stick of wood gives them answers! For a spirit of whoredom has led them astray, and they have left their God to play the whore.
verses.comment: Idolatry is portrayed as spiritual adultery. The text stresses the emptiness of material idols, deepening the New Testament call to worship in spirit and truth (John 4:24).

verses.text: They sacrifice on the tops of the mountains and burn offerings on the hills, under oak, poplar, and terebinth, because their shade is pleasant. Therefore your daughters play the whore, and your brides commit adultery.
verses.comment: The use of high places for worship condemned by God, indicating syncretism. The resulting moral corruption points to the spiritual consequences of false worship, and affirms the necessity of worshipping as God prescribes.

verses.text: I will not punish your daughters when they play the whore, nor your brides when they commit adultery, for the men themselves go aside with prostitutes and sacrifice with cult prostitutes, so a people without understanding will come to ruin.
verses.comment: God’s focus falls on the entire community’s guilt, especially the men, not just the outwardly scandalous. True judgment considers intent and heart, a principle reinforced by Christ’s teachings (Matt. 5:27-28).

verses.text: Though you, Israel, play the whore, let not Judah become guilty. Do not go to Gilgal, nor ascend to Beth-aven, and do not swear, 'As the LORD lives.'
verses.comment: Gilgal and Beth-aven (house of wickedness) are symbolic for centers of false worship. The warning draws a distinction between Israel and Judah at this stage, hinting at the future unity God desires for His people (cf. John 10:16).

verses.text: Like a stubborn heifer, Israel is stubborn; can the LORD now pasture them like a lamb in broad pasture?
verses.comment: Stubbornness is contrasted with the image of a trusting, obedient flock cared for by the Shepherd. This anticipates Jesus as the Good Shepherd (John 10:11).

verses.text: Ephraim is joined to idols; leave him alone.
verses.comment: Ephraim often stands for the Northern Kingdom. Persistent idolatry brings about abandonment—a severe mystery echoed in Paul’s 'giving them up' to their own desires—showing the gravity of repeated, unrepented sin.

verses.text: When their drink is gone, they give themselves to whoring; their rulers dearly love shame.
verses.comment: Leaders set a corrupt example; their devotion to vice leads the people astray. This shows the importance of upright spiritual leadership, which tradition maintains is exercised through those legitimately set apart and accountable for souls.

verses.text: A wind has wrapped them in its wings, and they shall be ashamed because of their sacrifices.
verses.comment: The 'wind' may symbolize both judgment and the vanity of idolatry. Shame is the natural consequence of false worship, pointing to the need for true obedience and right sacrifice, fulfilled in the perfect offering of Christ (see Heb. 9:14).
